poll_list.title: Ratification Poll for Core Unit Offboarding (COM-001) (MIP39c3-SP7) - January 9, 2023
poll_list.option: Approve Offboarding, 60,700 DAI Golden Parachute and 80% Multiplier for retroactive MKR - additional 85,854 DAI

content.content: MIP39c3-SP7: Core Unit Offboarding (COM-001)  Preamble MIP39c3-SP#: 7 Author(s): @Davidutro Contributors: Tags: com-001 Status: Accepted Date Proposed: 2022-12-06 Date Ratified: 2023-01-23 Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip39c3-sp7-core-unit-offboarding-com-001/19068 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmV9iktK Extra: The winning option was Option 1 (80% Multiplier - 156.098 Total MKR | 85,854 DAI Equivalent Value). The amounts under _Payment_ have been set accordingly, as was the multiplier under _Sources and Data_.   Sentence Summary This is an offboarding proposal for the GovComms Core Unit that includes both a golden parachute and retroactive MKR compensation.  Specification  Core Unit ID COM-001  Motivation MakerDAO is restructuring in accordance with the Endgame Plan. With the rejection of our last budget proposal, we’ve been advised by the leading delegates that work related to our mandate would be better executed as an ecosystem actor or as an in-house function within other stakeholder groups. The rejection of our budget proposal did not come with a complementary offboarding proposal, so we are putting it up ourselves. This core unit should be formally offboarded to support the transition, formalize the status of the team, and provide any “golden parachute” compensation and retroactive benefits due to contributors.  Facilitator With the offboarding of this Core Unit, the offboarding of the Facilitator is implied.  Deliverables and Responsibilities Administrative responsibilities:  Managing relationships with our accounting and payroll service providers Managing the Operational Multisig Managing the Continuous Operations Multisig Participation in the Ambassador Program as a multisig signer Paying invoices Publishing monthly financials  Active programs:  Calendars  Calls Votes and Important Dates   Call Support  Attendance tracking Banners/Thumbnails Hosting Summaries Slide Decks Strategy   Communication Platform Stewardship  Forum Moderation Subreddit Moderation Forum Information Architecture Design Tag correction   Emergency Communications Support  Pager Duty Coordination w/TECHOPs Emergency Playbook   Stakeholder Alignment  Participate in Decentralized Operations Initiative Host Monthly Collateral Management Initiative Planning Host Monthly Security Initiative Planning   Stakeholder Content  Aggregated Monthly CU Updates Weekly Relay Weekly Forum Recap   Stakeholder Database Stakeholder Notices  Vault Offboarding Notices as required by MIP62   Trackers  External  All Available Dashboards Tracker All Available Guides Tracker Office Hours Tracker Initiatives Tracker Discord Server Tracker Publications Tracker   Internal  Call Support Tracker Current Events Tracker Services and Owners Tracker Offboarding Checklist Publications Tracker DAO Accounts for Zoom Event-Specific Trackers for Attendees, Speakers, and Resources       Core Unit Unwinding – Work The active facilitator, @Davidutro, will execute the unwinding of the Core Unit with expected completion by the end of January 2023.  Administrative responsibilities   The last contributor invoices will be paid in the first week of January. Financial statements for both December and January will be published. An agreement will be made with accountable to administer the severance package in February, assuming this proposal passes. All excess funds will be returned from AccountAble and the Operational Multisig. The Continuous Operations Multisig will have its funds returned. An agreement will be made for the ambassador program multisig to replace us. We will verify that all intangible assets are appropriately licensed and that any transferable assets be transferred to the appropriate parties.   Active Programs   Following the budget rejection, we worked with the GovAlpha Core Unit to transition the critical and most valuable parts of our work. We are on track to close or transition all of our work by the end of December.   Core Unit Unwinding – Funds  One-time expense associated with unwinding  2x $350 offboarding charges from the payroll provider Severance Packages for full-time team members Retroactive MKR benefit compensation January compensation for Facilitator January expense for accounting & payroll services   Golden Parachute These amounts will be transferred through the Executive Vote that follows the ratification of this proposal, contingent upon the completion of the Core Unit’s unwinding as signified by the successful transition of work items, return of all excess funds, publication of all financials, and the closure of the continuous operations multisig.     Detail Amount (DAI)     3 months of Facilitator Compensation & Healthcare costs 35950   3 months of PM Compensation & Healthcare costs 24750   Total 60700     Retroactive MKR Compensation  Summary Govcomms did not prioritize getting an MKR compensation package in place early on. Instead, we decided to prioritize our actual work while waiting to see if a preferred standard would emerge by the end of the year. That never happened and so we planned to publish our proposal, modeled after GovAlpha’s, for RFC in December 2022, so it could be voted on in January, in time for what would have been our first 1-year cliff vest in February(under the GovAlpha model). Since the Core Unit has been defunded, we added our retroactive MKR compensation here as a part of our offboarding. During the RFC period of this proposal, we polled recognized delegates about their preference for paying out in MKR or the DAI equivalent value, DAI equivalent value won.  Formula MKR Compensation will be derived based on the salary earned within the Core Unit during the retroactive eligibility period. This proposal would compensate team members in MKR in the amount of  80%, 100%, or 120% multiplied by the DAI earned during the eligibility period divided by the moving average of MKR over the eligibility period to derive the MKR token amount for each contributor. MKR amount = DAI earned x multiplier% / $1737.12 DAI Eqivalent = MKR amount x current price  Sources and Data Current Price - Approximate price on 12-26-2022 $550.00 Eligibility Period - From inception to last day of approved budget: August 1st, 2021 through December 31st, 2021 Lockup - Determined during the RFC period. None. MKR Moving Average - Is derived from the “Close” price on CoinGecko (latest data point per day, UTC), taking the average closing price for that eligibility period. See spreadsheet for data. Price: $1737.12 Multiplier% - Determined by the proposal’s on-chain vote result. TBD Token - Token used for the payout was determined during the RFC period. DAI  Payments @Davidutro Golden Parachute Payment: 35950 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x1eE3ECa7aEF17D1e74eD7C447CcBA61aC76aDbA9 @Artem_Gordon Golden Parachute Payment: 24750 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x1eE3ECa7aEF17D1e74eD7C447CcBA61aC76aDbA9 @Davidutro Retroactive Bonus Payment: 43059.78 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x1eE3ECa7aEF17D1e74eD7C447CcBA61aC76aDbA9 @Artem_Gordon Retroactive Bonus Payment: 27439.97 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x1eE3ECa7aEF17D1e74eD7C447CcBA61aC76aDbA9 Alec Horner Retroactive Bonus Payment: 1335.49 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x50D2f29206a76aE8a9C2339922fcBCC4DfbdD7ea Andrea Suáreze Retroactive Bonus Payment: 1982.65 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0xeD27986bf84Fa8E343aA9Ff90307291dAeF234d3 Ashton Playsted Retroactive Bonus Payment: 714.39 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x3dfE26bEDA4282ECCEdCaF2a0f146712712e81EA Bernard Agrest Retroactive Bonus Payment: 1375.13 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x74520D1690348ba882Af348223A30D760BCbD72a Brandon Lewandowski Retroactive Bonus Payment: 582.57 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x471C5806cadAFB297D9b95B914B65f626fDCD1a7 Constanza Pregal Petrinec Retroactive Bonus Payment: 1025.84 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x051cCee0CfBF1Fe9BD891117E85bEbDFa42aFaA9 Gala Retroactive Bonus Payment: 630.83 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x1c138352C779af714b6cE328C9d962E5c82EBA07 Iván Berestein Retroactive Bonus Payment: 254.56 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0x55f2E8728cFCCf260040cfcc24E14A6047fF4d31 Larry Wu Retroactive Bonus Payment: 1757.73 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0xE004DAabEfe0322Ac1ab46A3CF382a2A0bA81Ab4 Mario Ferrari Retroactive Bonus Payment: 3012.92 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0xC2bE81CeB685eea53c77975b5F9c5f82641deBC8 Po Kunfu Retroactive Bonus Payment: 2682.16 DAI sent from the Surplus Buffer to 0xdB7c1777b5d4502b3d1228c2449F1816EB507748  Possible remedy to avoid offboarding None.  Ratification Vote The vote for this proposal shall be in Ranked Choice (IRV) format, featuring the following options:  Option 1: 80% Multiplier - 156.098 Total MKR | 85,854 DAI Equivalent Value Option 2: 100% Multiplier - 195.122 Total MKR | 107,317.50 DAI Equivalent Value (CU-Preferred) Option 3: 120% Multiplier - 234.147 Total MKR | 128,781 DAI Equivalent Value Option 4: Reject Offboarding I set the poll up so Delegates can choose up to two options.  I would appreciate your participation @Recognized-Delegates @trust_level_3 poll   _ The polls below are to inform us what to set in our proposal before the freeze period. Additionally, please see the complementary request for January winddown spend.     GovComms Winddown Spending Permission Governance   GovComms Winddown Spending Permission  Context We’re in a unique situation.  Govcomm’s current active budget expires on 12/31/22. With our last budget proposal, SP84, rejected, we are winding down the Core Unit and formally proposing its offboarding.  As detailed in the offboarding proposal, there are some administrative tasks that need to be completed in the month of January. Unfortunately, we don’t have any spend approved past the new year and we don’t feel comfortable spending without some f…

As an early MKR holder, this appears insane and short-sighted. For those of us outside the top [5] whales, we rely on their content and organization to follow our investment. Unless I’m missing something, this is sad.
Can I see the vote talleys without voting?

smartcontracts:  As an early MKR holder, this appears insane and short-sighted. For those of us outside the top [5] whales, we rely on their content and organization to follow our investment. Unless I’m missing something, this is sad.   I appreciate you voicing this. I said very similar things. Hopefully, we will be able to do similar work from a different position in the near future.     psychonaut:  Can I see the vote talleys without voting?   I set it so that you can. No one has voted yet though, I suspect that’s why the option to show results isn’t active.
The proposed minimum severance of 25% is the equivalent of a one year salary for billions of people across the world.

flipflopflapdelegate:  The proposed minimum severance of 25% is the equivalent of a one year salary for billions of people across the world.   Respectfully,  It’s not severance, but retroactive compensation. You didn’t say that when you voted 300% on GovAlpha’s proposal back in February.
sucks to see the CU being off boarded, i see the benefits of this CU. sadly, uncertain why the existence of this CU is not a governance matter.
CU off boarding makes total sense if we’re rebranding Maker into “MakerDAO as presented by Monetalis” or “Allan Pedersen’s MakerDAO”, otherwise this kind of misallocation is completely bonkers.

Thanks for being proactive about this. Very much appreciated. One thing: GovComms are not employees of MakerDAO, as the DAO cannot have employees. So a severance is surely impossible. I get what you mean, and that this is a technicality, still, words matter.
I fixed the language in the proposal replacing “Severance” with “Golden Parachute” since that’s the preferred term.
Not gonna comment on the offboarding, but the compensation amount is insanely high. Wow.

Thank you for your long service and care and integrity with which you performed this work. I’m so pleased we had a chance to meet in person at ETHDenver early in my Delegate work for ACREinvest. @Davidutro you are an OG here and have been so loyal and concerned for MakerDAO and all its people inside the community and the wider world. The viscous cruelty with which this moment has arrived is a stain and a shame on this community, among other recent examples. It is a disgrace for people in governance and who flaunt their prominence and power such as @flipflopflapdelegate to try and shame you when they have had all transparency, cooperation and compliance FROM you regarding the rules of the road. In particular you have been persistent and consistent in asking for feedback, direction and input the entire time ACREinvest has been a part of this community. Our impression is that rarely has anything constructive been forthcoming in a manner and time that would have allowed you and your team even a chance to course correct or navigate to a better outcome than this. People critical of compensation or whatever details need to humble themselves enough to do some actual research as to why what particular facts are what they are and what responsibility lies where and with whom. We regret the process unfolding here and abdication by many in power here of an ethical duty to show empathy and basic human kindness. That said, I am excited for you and team who have enormous talent and fortitude. You will prosper in whatever you decided to do next. When one door closes, another one opens. Best regards, Kianga
To clarify, this budget is not for work during transition time but for offboarding?

Correct, this is not for work during the transition but a severance golden parachute for our offboarding + MKR retroactive compensation component for work done in the past. The transition itself will just be one month of keeping me on payroll plus winddown costs mostly to do with our accounting and payroll service providers. See  for detail    GovComms Winddown Spending Permission Governance   GovComms Winddown Spending Permission  Context We’re in a unique situation.  Govcomm’s current active budget expires on 12/31/22. With our last budget proposal, SP84, rejected, we are winding down the Core Unit and formally proposing its offboarding.  As detailed in the offboarding proposal, there are some administrative tasks that need to be completed in the month of January. Unfortunately, we don’t have any spend approved past the new year and we don’t feel comfortable spending without some f…

I rarely post here, but I feel I have to weigh in here and agree with @ACREinvest .  @Davidutro has been a community member and dedicated contributor to Maker from before the foundation days, through the foundation times and into the DAO.  He has always been a valuable member and his enthusiasm in introducing Maker to the broader community is remembered even by people who just met him once years ago. I haven’t had a lot of visibility into this process, but it certainly seems this offboarding is being done with a particular lack of empathy, especially for someone who has been such an important member of the community and Maker team. I am particularly disappointed to see the posts and votes advocating for granting David and Artem the absolute minimum MKR vest.  To put some numbers around it:  Their 100% retro vesting would result in moving a total of 159.8 MKR  The PauseProxy currently has 73,400 MKR Endgame is advocating minting 50-70k new MKR Delegates at the top of the compensation level get paid $144,000 per year for voting, or roughly $100k more than the 25% level  It seems wrong that David and Artem’s hard work and best faith efforts to do right by the DAO are being rewarded in this way. @Davidutro and @Artem_Gordon : Thank you for your work, I will miss all your contributions and your presence on the regular thursday gov calls and know that your talent will carry you on to great future adventures

I second all of @csmith comments. @Davidutro was the very first “Maker Fam” I ever met, before I joined the project I remember him manning the Maker booth at ETHDenver 2019. His enthusiasm was one one of the factors that brought me to join the project months later. He’s been what I’ve seen to be a solid constant in the project ever since, and his departure would certainly mark the end of an era in my opinion. Regarding the compensation, MKR holders and delegates should once again remember that everyone “working” for the DAO is doing so as a contract arrangement and so much of the comp to individuals is lost to business and compliance overhead. To second csmith’s point, you’ve all voted to dilute us anyways, so I’m not sure the reason to be penurious with a long-time fixture of the DAO. Regarding GovComms, I’m generally pretty busy with my own role, and don’t have time to troll forums all day. Having David and Artem separate the wheat from the chaff and summarize the happenings in weekly gov calls has been one of the primary ways I’ve been able to keep my finger on the pulse. I will notice it’s absence. I want to thank them for their work on the project and I hope that this isn’t the end of our future collaboration.

Per @flipflopflapdelegate’s suggestion on delegate office hours, here is a repoll with more granular options. I set the poll up so Delegates can choose up to two options. I would appreciate your participation @Recognized-Delegates @trust_level_3    What multiplier should GovComms use to calculate MKR Compensation?  25% 35% 45% 55% 65% 75% 85% 100%     0 voters

This is sad to see, don´t know the ins and outs but David has been basically from the beginning of time in Maker which is a lot in crypto years and Artem was really putting in the work with really clear and concise summaries among other tasks which will definitely be missed (aside from being a really nice person to talk to) by most of mkr hodlers who don´t follow closely the project. Even more than that it seems that part of the culture seems to be drifting too, all my empathy to this two amazing people and all the best going forward.
We have a lot of respect for @Davidutro since the Foundation days. So we hope the team successfully transitions to be a part of the Endgame whether that’s via separate structure or merging.

@csmith @brianmcmichael you folks are misunderstanding. This isn’t about @Davidutro  and @Artem_Gordon and the rest of the GovComms Core unit Members. We have always value their services and even supported the team early-on when some MKR token owners were under the impression the Core Unit concept was a waste of money. This isn’t about them—it’s about MKR token owners who don’t want the Surplus Buffer looted and the DAO being taken advantage of. Personally, I have know David since the Foundation days when he ran a community call that barely anybody here ever attended. I attended live and uncut with a few community members week after week, listening and supporting his calls. Rain or shine. I have dance for hours at DeFi Events next to David. I’ve broken bread with him, and had the pleasure of meeting Artem at EthDenver last year. This is an attempt at figuring out the fairness of providing a “Golden Parachute” to those Core Unit members that need to evolve into the Endgame. It’s about protecting MakerDAO and the need to send a clear message that this DAO is not a Cash Grab. And again, we are not stating that GovComms is doing a cash grab move here—but as you All know by now, MakerDAO will Pivot to the Endgame State. This isn’t the END for David and Artem. I believe they’ll have plenty of opportunities to blossom. As far as I can tell they can be added by as Free Agents by ANY Core Unit, or recruited to serve in clusters. They can also adopt as an ecosystem actor, councils, tribunals, or become a Governance SubDAO. This isn’t their last dance. Myself as a MKR token owner, I will always put MakerDAO first. And while you @csmith perhaps think that Recognized Delegates are over paid — remember that the first pawns to fall will be Recognized Delegates when push comes to shove. Just remember that when you think the money is what motivates me and I’m willing to be the first soldier in the firing line.

I would argue David is getting penalized because he didn’t try to loot MakerDAO. If he had asked for significant MKR compensation back in February like other CUs, he probably would have gotten it approved and would be getting a generous MKR severance right now(like RWF did). Instead, he decided to demonstrate value before asking for MKR comp, then an organization wide restructure got his CU offboarded in a bear market and he will be lucky if he gets a fraction of what he would have gotten.

I said this to David in private and I’ll reiterate this in public. I’m sorry for the outcome of the vote. I think it was unfair and unduly. You did excellent and very needed job for Maker. Imo, GovComm is crucial for any DAO. Endgame or not, offboarding should be done more gracefully. People have plans, families, commitments in the offchain world. DAOs are competing for the workforce with the corporate world. DeFi already has a reputation of a roller coaster in terms of job security. One of the key goals of the Endgame is to attract the new generation of qualified delegates and builders. People are already taking risks connecting their lives to the nascent field like DeFi. An organisation culture with soldiers and the firing line is not conducive for the DAO’s sustainable growth. What’s happening to David and Artem sends a message that if this happened to the OG’s like David and Artem, anybody can be in their shoes at any given moment.

CodeKnight:  If he had asked for significant MKR compensation back in February like other CUs, he probably would have gotten it approved and would be getting a generous MKR severance right now(like RWF did). Instead, he decided to demonstrate value before asking for MKR comp, then an organization wide restructure got his CU offboarded in a bear market   You’re absolutely right. 100% agree. As we spoke about it during the Delegate Office Hours the entire CU off-boarding process has been a nightmare since inception. Perhaps the next best approach should be to have the community come together and figure out a process that works best for everyone.Otherwise, off-boardings will continue to be a painful experience as market conditions could potentially deteriorate further.     pvl:  anybody can be in their shoes at any given moment.   Totally agree. Specially during these uncertain economic times of rampant inflation along with central banks simultaneously hiking rates — 2023 could see a further painful structural market correction and we can find ourselves in a situation of economic uncertainty. This keeps me up at night the most.

flipflopflapdelegate:  Myself as a MKR token owner, I will always put MakerDAO first. And while you @csmith perhaps think that Recognized Delegates are over paid — remember that the first pawns to fall will be Recognized Delegates when push comes to shove. Just remember that when you think the money is what motivates me and I’m willing to be the first soldier in the firing line.   Actually, I agree with you here on the risk/reward and was not saying Delegates are overpaid.  My point was more that your comment about “billions of people” is as irrelevant to GovComms as it is for Recognized Delegates or any DAO member.     flipflopflapdelegate:  This is an attempt at figuring out the fairness of providing a “Golden Parachute” to those Core Unit members that need to evolve into the Endgame.   There are two issues here the parachute (3 months pay) and the retroactive MKR vesting.  The poll is about the vesting.  I believe it would be fair to long time and valuable contributors to give them the same treatment as others (200% retroactive vesting) in the DAO have gotten especially when they tried to do right by the DAO at their own personal risk:     CodeKnight:  If he had asked for significant MKR compensation back in February like other CUs, he probably would have gotten it approved and would be getting a generous MKR severance right now   Which you seem to agree with:     flipflopflapdelegate:  You’re absolutely right. 100% agree.   so I’m not sure I understand your position of only rewarding 25-35% for the valuable services they provided over the last year… The DAO hasn’t figured out good offboarding, why punish David and Artem for that?

A little bit of motivational ventilation for everyone: We all agree that GovComms is not the last Core Unit to be offboarded or undergo the Endgame transition. The time has now come for us to commit the next few months to collective, pragmatic, workshop-based approaches to solving these questions. Maker’s future situation cannot be predicted; thus, the final decision may remain difficult for both parties. The fact that a DAO this large has developed ‘decentralized’ points of view is not surprising, but it is not necessarily a bad thing (looking beyond the current example). There are a number of challenges and targets on everyone’s plate, but we are actually fortunate to have the opportunity to work together at any time, on any day, from anywhere, hand in hand, to achieve bulls-eye solutions. The answer may lie somewhere in the middle, or it may not. This cannot and should not be decided by any single individual. Our membership in a DAO should not prevent us from working together as a strong community. Anyhow, there are still a few Delegate office hours left, and I suggest they be utilized now more than ever. Whether you are venting your opinion or creating charts, analyses, models, mind maps, SWOT analyses, etc., let’s use this precious time to structure the next set of calls to try to find a solution before the next round of budget polls is complete. P.s., Thank you all very much

@csmith I had a private conversation (via DM) with David prior to this public post and I personally was under the impression that we agreed that retroactive compensation for him would be more advantageous in DAI versus MKR—giving him the freedom to decide if buying MKR is beneficial to him personally. I can tell you as an American that I personally would choose DAI as retroactive compensation, as it has a tax advantage and allows you to keep your MKR versus having to liquidate to pay for any vested capital gains when reporting such. With that in mind—since the DAO does not have an off-boarding policy and I am not an attorney, nor do I have real-world life experience working for a Human Resources department—I reached out to some personal contacts that have real-life  experience in these matters. I was provided several opinions for severances/“golden parachutes”, and the unusual usage of “retroactive pay” which in the real-world means you owe money to an employee for services performed under an employee contract. As you might realize — some folks in the real world can’t comprehend what we do here in a DAO—it was difficult to explain this situation. I was provided the opinion that an employee without a vesting stock plan or employee contract does not constitute an employer providing retroactive pay. I was told that in certain instances, some companies may choose to accelerate unvested stock options, or to extend the post-termination exercise period, as a “goodwill gesture”.  I was also provided the opinion that perhaps a 3 month non-contractual retroactive pay would be a nice goodwill gesture for this instance. However, doing the above might set a bad precedent, or because a real-world organization can incur “significant accounting charges” by modifying the stock option grants—this is widely avoided. So, I don’t claim to have all the right answers—because if you provide this CU 100%, 200%, etc., does that mean every contributor should also get the same treatment? And if an offboarded employees walk away with large bonuses/retroactive benefits and then cluster into the endgame to earn more from MakerDAO is that fair to CUs that will still around for the next 12-months? I don’t know @csmith — I’m trying my best to figure it out. Please understand that Flip Flop Flap Delegate is only 1 of 21 recognized delegates and MKR token owners who can decide what is the right metric. And again, I never claim to have the right answers—I’m doing the best I can with the limited resources that I have—knowing that one day I’ll be in the same position, as we are All working on limited time. Nothing last forever. This I can assure you.

flipflopflapdelegate:  “retroactive pay” which in the real-world means you owe money to an employee for services performed under an employee contract. Whatever should be the agreed compensation, which I don’t have enough knowledge to comment what that amount should be, it should be in DAI. In the real world, if there was such plan for acquirement of the company’s stock, it would be options to purchase at $X vesting on X date.  Not creation of stock from thin air.  My guess is had something formal been set up in advance, some of the options given would have been at $1k/MKR or greater, i.e., they would now be worthless. I’ve been away from the Forum for quite awhile. One of the reasons I fell away was disillusionment. One of my reasons for disilluionment is the creation of MKR from thin air for compensation, when a key way to provide value to MKR holders is the sale of DAI for MKR and then burning the MKR. Printing MKR is contrary to that tenant and contrary to corporate governance.

brianmcmichael:  separate the wheat from the chaff    General to Governance  Offboarding Core Units  Is it unfair how Core Units are being treated? Is this something that the DAO should look to harmonize? How much consensus is enough? (knowing what happened with the MKR framework) Should we keep dealing with offboardings on a case-by-case basis?   Golden Parachutes  When should Core Units get them? How much should they be? Are these on top of any transition or winddown period?   MIPs  Is the vague text in the MIPs an agreement by Governance? Should precedence become law?   MKR  Since we will use a lot of MKR for other ventures, should we grant all the more minor requests? What is the limit to consider an MKR grant minor? Should every contributor get it?   Retroactive MKR  Should Core Units without an active MKR compensation be eligible for retroactive payment? If yes, will this kill experiments in the DAO, where Governance stops approving any cheap Core Unit because they might ask for more retroactively later?   Specific to this Poll  Forum Summaries  Are these useful? For how many people? For which type of people Would these people pay for them? Should this team keep doing it and charge a subscription?   GovComms  Did GovComms do the work properly? Was it a good deal for the DAO based on market conditions?   David (not even sure why this is on the table since the feeling seems to be unanimous)  Do we like David? Does he have good energy? Does he spread good vibes in general? Is he loyal and concerned for MakerDAO?

Proposal Edit: All contributors who’ve earned at least $1000 Dai with us have been given the opportunity to opt-in for the retroactive bonus compensation with December 23rd as a deadline. The last edit on the proposal is on the 28th, though I aim to finalize it by the 23rd.      iammeeoh:  compensation levels are insanely high.   A couple of people have said this on the thread now. Are you referring to the Salaries we received, the Golden Parachute, the retroactive bonus, or all of it together? For context, I set myself up with the lowest facilitator salary level(AFAIK) in the DAO – $120,000. I started Artem at $75,000 and gave him an annual raise for improved performance to $80,000. We paid contributors between $20 and $100 per hour depending on the work.  How much does a Director, Corporate Communications make in the United States? The average Director, Corporate Communications salary in the United States is $118,387 as of , but the salary range typically falls between $105,285 and $131,398. - source - Salary.com  The golden parachute is fair since other offboarded Core Units used 3 months of compensation as their standard. The retroactive compensation is fair given the packages that have been granted to other Core Units. (Full list - https://mips.makerdao.com/mips/list?search=$%20%23mkr-budget) So yes, the compensation is high. That was the cost of retaining Core Units as agreed by the DAO in all of these cases. It would be easier and less rewarding to get traditional jobs. Instead, we all embarked on the risky adventure of running independent teams at the DAO in public, with MKR token ownership as a part of our incentive. I think there is a reason why the DAO chose to reward teams in this way and it shouldn’t be lost in the conversation.

Disclaimer: I am European so perhaps some things are different. Feel free to correct me.     Davidutro:  How much does a Director, Corporate Communications make in the United States?   Director of Corporate communications is generally assumed to be a role requiring something like 7+ years of corporate communications experience and a few years of experience managing teams. You had 1 year, maybe 2?, of experience prior to the CU (or at least this is what emerged when you presented your CV) and no significant management experience. So yeah, I suspect in a traditional company your profile would have been more realistically this:   Salary.com    Corporate Communications Associate Salary | Salary.com The average Corporate Communications Associate salary in the United States is $61,807 as of November 23, 2022, but the salary range typically falls between $56,627 and $67,235.          Davidutro:  So yes, the compensation is high. That was the cost of retaining Core Units as agreed by the DAO in all of these cases.   True! The DAO agreed to pay “above market” prices (also in your case) because:  we were in the middle of a bull market, and indeed, working for a DAO carries additional risks like lack of security of the position in the middle-long (or even short) terms, legal risks, etc.  The high salaries provided an acceptable (for both MakerDAO and CUs) compromise covering all these risks. Now, if your CU is being off-boarded, well, you should look at it as part of the risk which has already been accounted for in the compensation package.     Davidutro:  The severance golden parachute is fair since other offboarded Core Units used 3 months of compensation as their standard.   I am not arguing with this point. If it was done for others, why not for you? This is a fair point, imho, and MKR-holders should consider it carefully.

Regardless of my experience, the DAO did not hire me as a junior associate but as the facilitator/director of a team. And judging by the feedback I received both in public and private, I didn’t do a bad job.

Davidutro:  Regardless of my experience, the DAO did not hire me as a junior associate but as the facilitator/director of a team. And judging by the feedback I received both in public and private, I didn’t do a bad job by any means.   You did a good job, and it is indeed one of the first things I said. You asked me to expand on why some people think the salaries/parachutes are insanely high and I answered in good faith. Maybe I am wrong or blinded. Again, I thank you @Davidutro for your work.

I have some thoughts that I’d like to add to this discussion, while also acknowledging that I am one of the above contributors that stands to benefit financially. I’ll also add that the financial benefit would be nice, but wouldn’t likely exceed $2-4,000. Not life changing money by any measure (at least, for me.) I think that the core question being asked here is: What level of retroactive compensation (two parts to this, golden parachute and retroactive back-pay) should David and Artem receive? There are a number of options and opinions provided here, but what I’m not seeing much of is a discussion on what should go into this decision. I’d like to offer the following ideas as a place to start:  Looking at historical patterns and trends for similar offboarding/MKR retroactive compensation. Ideally this is contextualized to CU’s that have done similar type work and/or longevity within the community. Whether or not the team and its members provided valuable support and were regarded in good standing. Whether or not here is evidence that leads of a CU put the DAO above their own financial interests. Commitment and involvement in the DeFi space more broadly.  But, before I get into the above, I’d like to address some points that I consider are being made in an ill-considered manner. I’ll also add that my opinions below are made in the context of my own career - I have over a decade of experience, more than half of it in roles that require me to hire and manage people/teams/functions as well as manage and set budgets for departments.   @iammeeoh David’s work experience prior to joining the community has absolutely no bearing on what his salary offer was, nor should it have been. He was hired into a new, volatile, promising industry based on his passion for it, his ability to network and make powerful connections within it and because he had clear strengths that convinced someone to give him a position as a leader. Especially in David’s case, as an early adopter who landed a role at Maker precisely because he provided clear value before being paid anything. If those in charge of approving his salary deemed it reasonable, then looking BACK at that and saying ‘he was overpaid’ isn’t fair and entirely misses the point. The onus should be on those setting a salary, not those receiving it. This also creates the potential for people to be punished for advocating for themselves, retroactively, which could ultimately lead to a zero-sum culture. Additionally, if he didn’t do a good job in the role - which by all accounts, even those advocating for a lower compensation package agree that he did - , why was a raise approved? Why were increased budgets for his team, and staff approved?   Compensation itself → People should be paid based on the job they are doing, not what they were doing before or what someone subjectively ‘thinks’ they should be making. Organizations usually create a range for what they consider a fair salary for a given position. Clearly David and his team fell in line with that range. The time for deciding whether or not a role had a fair salary range is WAY past due. If anything, there’s an argument to be made here that both David and Artem were pulling in salaries LOWER than they could have commanded elsewhere. Both, because despite their ‘lack of experience’  they are highly capable and because they are in a high risk industry. People receive incredibly high salaries in crypto, partially because they can get fired or lose so much from the day-to-day. I can only imagine that David’s connections and status within the broader community meant that he was being offered more money elsewhere, which he did not take. (Which as an aside, indicates his commitment to Maker.) a. As a note in favor of parity, I’ll add that there are three other CU’s being offboarded at the moment. There doesn’t seem to be this level of tension in the offboarding proposals for those. I’m curious why not?   Connecting with HR folks here seems both a little pointless and a little biased. Reasonable HR employees will look at these discussions and come up with various opinions, looking at the same information. The problem is that this situation IS NOT comparable to a traditional organization. MakerDao runs in a drastically different way from a traditional corporation and this ultimately becomes an ‘apples to oranges’ comparison. This is particularly striking in this CU’s case because it specifically chose to not adopt a model for MKR compensation, because it was 1) hoping to see the community come to a consensus and 2) wanted to prove their worth before moving forward with a proposal. Other CUs did so, within an inflated market, to individual financial benefit (this is absolutely not a judgement on anyone doing that, btw.) Regardless, it doesn’t seem like HR has routinely  (or maybe, even ever) been consulted in the past. So, why now? I’m not privy to what’s happening behind the scenes, but I think that this is a fair question to ask, especially given this communities commitment to transparency.   The comment about ‘billons of people’ seems entirely random. Who cares? Those people aren’t in this discussion, and have no bearing whatsoever to either David/Artem’s value-add (or, if we’re playing that game) personal financial situation. I truly believe this is moving the goal post and doesn’t add anything of value to this discussion. Unless this has been the consistent position by @flipflopflapdelegate every single time this situation has come up, I’m curious to see why it’s been brought into the equation, now. (And, I maintain that even if that WAS the position, it still has nothing to do with the conversation at hand.)   Now, to discuss what I think - and why I think it - should go into a compensation package here:   The DAO has yet to standardize how offboarding a CU should be handled from a financial perspective. That is clearly a missed opportunity, one that creates tensions, potential charges of favoritism, etc, etc. I personally think that when considering for something like this we’d want to group CUs into categories of ‘types of work’ which then would get their own ‘range’ of payment. Why, because not all work is created equal and there is intense competition for some roles and not others - especially on the technical side of things. The other part of this should focus on longevity in the community. Personally, I think that the more dedication and care you’ve shown, the more you should be rewarded, but I’m willing to be moved away from that point of view. Regardless, because this hasn’t been done yet it seems unfair to punish one CU, especially when recent CUs have not received that treatment. It’s one thing to see this applied consistently across the board, but to me, this seems like a CU is being treated disproportionately harshly than others. (This is also exactly why a standardized process should be created and approved ASAP, so that we’re not putting ourselves in this situation again.) |   Whether or not a CU’s and its members are providing valuable support and are in good standing should matter, particularly for CUs like COM-001 which offers a more back-bone, operational type of support. This type of support enables team and organizations but often goes unrewarded and ignored. When things are going smoothly, no-one thinks to highlight these types of teams, and when they’re going wrong, these teams are the first (generally) to take the brunt of the blame. From what I’ve seen everyone here unanimously agrees that COM-001 provided valuable support and that David/Artem provided good quality work and were highly regarded. I think that when we consider what the value of the compensation package here should be, we take that into account.|   I think more broadly (in a world with an SOP for these situations) this shouldn’t be taken into account, but I do want to elevate what a few others have said. David routinely put his CU and Maker above his own financial interests. If he had done what others had historically done this would not even be a conversation. This is NOT to condemn or judge anyone, BUT, I do think that this type of behavior should be acknowledged. If anything, this could theoretically serve to incentivize bad actors who try to secure their own financial security, at the expense of Maker, precisely because they’re following what is happening here. Communities like this won’t be able to succeed, let alone thrive, if those in charge of individual CU’s are making sure they ‘get-theirs’ before anything else happens.|   The crypto world is small and while it’s growing everyone is probably two degrees of separation from everyone else. And, people (being people) are going to hold grudges. Instead of good business dictating what happens, situations like this hurt feelings, ultimately creating ‘Us vs. Them coalitions.’ This could be especially true for ‘Alumni’ of Maker who are very possibly going to end up in the industry and similar capacities, and who will take with them their experiences. Having Alumni (or even current staff) leave feeling jilted out of their compensation (or their experiences being offboarded) will get around. In the long-run, I believe that’ll be bad for Maker. It’ll discourage people from boomeranging back to work at Maker and folks will consider avoiding Maker in their job process. Sure, that’s a pretty bleak scenario, but it’s one that plays out everywhere all the time. I’d even argue that because we’re so transparent and in such an inter-connected time that potential impact could be felt faster than other organizations might. But reverse is true, strong, empathetic and orderly offboarding processes could encourage people to come back to Maker and place it as an organization that top-tier talent wants to work at.

Again a bit late to the party.  My $.02DAI for free as usual now. First @Davidutro to me you have always been responsive and courteous.   You had probably the second most reasonable budget for what the DAO got.  I think GovAlpha may still be the lowest generally but debating what CU is the best value for the money is an exercise in politics imo. I think this DAO will miss you should you decide to go elsewhere. I agree with many of the comments and share many of the sentiments in the posts by @ACREinvest @csmith @brianmcmichael I completely agree with the following by @CodeKnight     CodeKnight:  I would argue David is getting penalized because he didn’t try to loot MakerDAO.   I know for a fact David did quite a bit to shave budget proposals down, pretty much giving up COL increases to get a budget passed and in fact not seeking the best terms for his CU is basically hurting him and his team at this point. Not even going to get into the consistency and fairness issues here. One thing regarding value of MKR vesting for severance or golden parachute here: I agree with @omahalawyer     omahalawyer:  In the real world, if there was such plan for acquirement of the company’s stock, it would be options to purchase at $X vesting on X date. Not creation of stock from thin air. My guess is had something formal been set up in advance, some of the options given would have been at $1k/MKR or greater, i.e., they would now be worthless.   The point is that MKR wasn’t being given as options.   The debate on how to compensate in a way that encourages alignment of CU interests with MKR holders (in terms of value creation vs. destruction) imo wasn’t optimal. My problem here is that the MKR vested is being equated to 1.7K DAI/MKR and that given every MKR holder has taken the ride down from 4K to now $550 and the vesting cliff would have been hitting around this price I don’t think it is fair to equate MKR vesting value to a DAI value of 1.7K.   That part just won’t fly for me. Give them MKR and let them sell it just like everyone else has to do to pay gains, but don’t just manufacture a value more than 3x current market and pay out in DAI as I don’t think that is fair to MKR holders and generally sets a bad precedent.   No-one gets paid in cash in lieu of stock on termination of employments unless there is some great buyout offer or some particularly good reason for a company to do so.   I don’t see the overwhelming reason to pay out MKR vesting value in DAI unless you adjust this to market value of the MKR on day of vesting or payout or some such. Willing to hear cogent arguments here on this part. The rest regarding the total mistreatment of the people who are MakerDAO contractors, just leaves a bad taste in my mouth and ache in my heart.   If work abuse is what Decentralization brings, I can’t wait for regulation good or bad.   The fact that DAOs can’t make enforceable formal contract agreements pretty much says it all to me at this point.

MakerMan:  My problem here is that the MKR vested is being equated to 1.7K DAI/MKR and that given every MKR holder has taken the ride down from 4K to now $550 and the vesting cliff would have been hitting around this price I don’t think it is fair to equate MKR vesting value to a DAI value of 1.7K. That part just won’t fly for me.   @MakerMan, that’s not how the formula works. Since the payout value is the multiplier x dai earned, the Dai value is fixed, only governed by the multiplier. It doesn’t hurt to run a sentiment poll so Recognized-Delegates I am once again asking for your opinions  EDIT: Closed Poll

Davidutro:  Since the payout value is tied to the multiplier x dai earned, the Dai value is fixed, only being governed by the multiplier. MKR value only dictates how much MKR we would get paid out, not the Dai equivalent value.   So a key component missing is the MKR moving price. Under GovAlpha’s model the multiplier is applied to DAI and then assigned to MKR based on the moving average. Without a moving average you get DAI at no discount. Not to say that may not be an appropriate way to do things, but worth noting with the model. In this example if a 6-month moving average was applied the MKR price point would be ~700 which would cut into the capital dispersed. Without a moving average for the MKR price-point, GovAlpha’s model results in quite a bit of MKR allocation in present market condition. To David’s point, if the transaction is being done in DAI then you just apply this idea to the percentage you support. But voters should be mindful that it won’t be an apples to apples comparison with GovAlpha’s model.

MakerMan:  The rest regarding the total mistreatment of the people who are MakerDAO contractors, just leaves a bad taste in my mouth and ache in my heart. If work abuse is what Decentralization brings, I can’t wait for regulation good or bad. The fact that DAOs can’t make enforceable formal contract agreements pretty much says it all to me at this point.    What? You’re pretty much saying: We cannot decide ourselves on some rules to treat people fairly and make sure no one loots the DAO, so someone else should come and do it for us, good or bad. Decentralization doesn’t bring work abuse. The lack of pre-established agreements does, and we have people having different expectations (as a contributor or as a DAO-defender) hoping to get a good deal. For the longest time, we have left governance design as an afterthought, and we have had people waiting for someone else to come up with agreements and frameworks.

juan:  You’re pretty much saying: We cannot decide ourselves on some rules to treat people fairly and make sure no one loots the DAO, so someone else should come and do it for us, good or bad.   I had a longer winded response but to clarify what I am saying is that blockchain has codes that define rules for its operation.   When it comes to people DAOs do not.     In contrast when it comes to companies, there are well defined rules as to what is and IS NOT allowed in contracts and to personal treatment.  There are real rights and responsibilities that are enforceable by law.   Decentralization by its very nature in effect is trying to build a system where code is law and what we are beginning to see is that this doesn’t apply well to people who are connected to these cryptographic keys, and the networks that operate to blockchain code machinery.

Davidutro:  @MakerMan, that’s not how the formula works. Since the payout value is the multiplier x dai earned, the Dai value is fixed, only governed by the multiplier. MKR value only dictates how much MKR we would get paid out if we were to get MKR instead of DAI.   Sorry @Davidutro  I probably don’t understand the whole multiplier issue and ultimately you don’t have to placate me at all because I won’t be deciding this issue - delegates/rune will. I guess my point here is when it comes to any form of contractor (or worker) compensation in enterprise value (in this case MKR) converting this value to cash requires extra thought since this conversion rarely happens in real world cases.  These things have vesting times because these rewards have to have a longer commitment, and the value of them is directly connected to ALL investors.   To my mind it makes sense to just honor the existing agreed commitment in MKR and let people keep or sell it.  I personally find that watching whether people sell of hold will tell the DAO much more about how people that worked intimately with Maker feel about its future prospects than any other single measure. As a former contractor I understand that there are tax consequences that likely will force sale of some of the acquired MKR.  Whether the contractor decides to sell it all, ultimately up to their view on MKR represents any value to them or not longer term.

Based on the above I would be voting for MKR as the compensation method and then just having to decide on how much.  If I was voting it would be 100% MKR :).   170K/yrly rate seems steep to me (but hell the hazards of working at a DAO n’ all that).  Unemployment would be at most 12 weeks which would work out to about 40K (12/52*170) which I think would be reasonably generous.  (this would come out to about 72.72 MKR if it was paid in MKR. If this compensation is some sort of severance then pay in DAI based on some reasonable thinking but don’t mix the two at this 1.737K/MKR value.

Did you get the OK from the contributors to publish all their names with compensation? I think I wouldn’t be thrilled. Edit: “with compensation” to make it clearer.

Contributor names have always been public, with the active list on our transparency dashboard, govcomms.makerdao.network. This was disclaimed to each individual when they agreed to contribute with us. Additionally, we allowed contributors to use custom names if they so desired.

This is a summary of the potential impact of this proposal, from GovAlpha’s perspective:  This is a valid Core Unit offboarding subproposal under the currently approved governance process. This proposal aims to offboard the Governance Communications Core Unit (COM-001). It includes a golden parachute of 60,700 DAI and retroactive MKR compensation. The unwinding plan will be carried out by the current Facilitator. The execution details are included in this subproposal. Upon ratification of this MIP, GovAlpha Core Unit (GOV-001) will take over all Active Programs. This proposal has been assigned High-Impact based on the methodology listed here.  Disclaimer: These summaries are intended to be a guide and not a source of truth. You remain responsible for any actions you take on the grounds of this information. Please note the date when the summary was last updated to judge accuracy. Updated 2022-12-26

@Recognized-Delegates @MIP-Editors The final edits to the proposal have been published.  We’re running this as a Ranked Choice vote with options for the multiplier. The payout is set to be in the DAI equivalent value. Contributor inclusion has been finalized. Minor format and wording improvements. Tables were added for the ranked-choice options of 80%, 100%, and 120%.      prose11:  So a key component missing is the MKR moving price. Under GovAlpha’s model the multiplier is applied to DAI and then assigned to MKR based on the moving average. Without a moving average you get DAI at no discount.   Also, this was fixed. The DAI equivalent value takes into account the MKR moving price, drastically lowering the DAI payouts as compared what we originally had–hence the higher multiplier choices. DAI payout from the original 25% multiplier is comparable to the DAI payout amount on the 80% multiplier with the fix to the formula.
@MIP-Editors I would like to formally submit this proposal for the January 2023 cycle.

Please note I have amended the text of this proposal to clarify that DAI payments will be made from the Surplus Buffer and not the Pause Proxy if an offboarding package is approved by voters. This is a technical clarification and does not affect the substance, or the submission of this proposal. The Pause Proxy is not a typical source of DAI payments and only holds ~35 DAI at present.
This proposal is currently being voted on. Its Ratification Poll will run until 2023-01-23. Please vote here.
